data.message:
in our small startup(two web devs) our current apps each have a nodejs server which communicates with several dbs and provides data to their client. we use auth0 to implement authentication via JWTs. 
we want to take our architecture to the next level, and create one rest api server which can serve all apps as well as authentication.
taking into account that this effort should take days and not weeks\months, and also that we have a very small amount of users for our apps, what services\tools would you recommend to achieve this?
I didn't understand the question. You current setup already “serves all apps as well as authentication”, or does it?

Unify your mongodb databases (I think you should be using mongodb) and create separate collections for each database. Mongodb uses schemas to achieve this. e.g you should have one schema for users, another for articles, products and so on. As an extra tip, I suggest using concurrently to startup your react front end and node backend at once.
unify with graphql and take it to the next^2 level
https://medium.freecodecamp.org/rest-apis-are-rest-in-peace-apis-long-live-graphql-d412e559d8e4
I know that. But be specifically asked for a REST solution

Having worked extensively designing REST APIs, and having used GraphQL in production for a couple of months now, I can safely say that it is seriously worth considering as an option, even on particularly large apps.

I would not be saying this, were it not for the mention of having *multiple* backend databases/APIs ─ GraphQL's resolver pattern is extremely nice when working with multiple backend services, as well as allowing easy migrations when swapping those services out for new ones.
Julian, he wants a REST API

Yes, activeStatus is always a string, so it will not caused any "undefined" error.

for your 'isNameExists' routine, if you are running through a catalogues map of thousands of objects to collect a list of object names, perhaps instead you can say something like this...

const existsInCatalogue = catalogues.some(
        data => data.name === name
    )

this would go through your catalogue and compare the data object to your props name value, and will break the loop when a true condition is evaluated (implicit arrow function will return the result of the comparison)

then you can say something a bit more elegant in your if statements to say if(!name){} else if(existsInCatalogue) else {} to handle your component state (or perhaps a ternary expression or even a switch statement)

I dont know why 'activeStatus' is a string, it seems like this should  be a boolean, along with your state properties 'nameValidation' and 'activeStatusValidation'.

Lastly, you could even pull the actual validation logic handling out of this method and into its own, so that 'inputValidation' strictly handles comparing the name prop to check if it exists in the catalogue, and returning some sort of boolean value, or invoking a validation handler with the result.

So many questions about this code. Is activeStatus always a string? Current evaluation will not catch fail cases where activeStatus is undefined as an example. A few things.

First, the checks seem in reverse priority with the last two looking like they may possibly never run. First things first check if the activeStatus is in the correct state and return out if not. Otherwise, proceed to destructure the state and props. Next simply check if there is a value for name and handle the case that there is not by setting whatever state you see fit and returning.

U can still validate the the access token in ur child component, if one of the child component returns true then u can store n refresh

I had such a scenario in my application not exactly but similar. I was supposed to integrate my app with adfs ( single sign on) and custom authorisation module, in this case I had to update the adfs user token once it was expired, n based on the token expiry I should authorise my user. To solve this I forced validated in each child components redux actions to validate the adfs token then proceed on the authorisation.

This is heavily reliant on the fact the view part and assumes there is always a parent component that makes refresh token requests, and other components are waiting for the new token. It is possible to totally abstract it from the view, but it gets more complicated. Perhaps redux observables have recipes for those scenarios, because it deals with observables. I haven't tried it though.
Anh Dao my main concern is the child components waiting to make the call
Well they have to wait for the new token anyway. They can't make a call with an expired token.
Anh Dao yes but by default they will and the call will fail, so I’m asking how would you approach having them wait once the “EXPIRED” action has gone out
observable pattern comes to mind.
Similar to how you do htmlElement.on('click', ...), you can do it in any object. httpProvider.on('tokenRefreshed', ...) .
That requires something like redux observables
maybe
Never used observables with react, what do you use RxJS?
I see
I didn't use it with React. I used it with Angular4.
I have very limited experience there.
but I do have experience with event emitters that can make observable patterns, but it may be too low-level.
Yes same
Ok great stuff, thanks 🙂

I don't have that in my app, but I have a http wrapper that makes HTTP requests.
Anytime the API responsds with 401, it dispatches a LOGOUT action.

For your case, maybe you can try getting the http wrapper to check if token expired or not?
If it has expired, attempt a "refresh token" sequence to refresh the token.

However, if child components are firing multiple http requests all requiring latest access token,
then, you want to avoid duplicate refresh token requests.

To do that, the simplest way I can think of is for the parent component to do the refresh token,
while other child components' http requests are put on "waiting for new token mode" for the events:
- if refresh token succeeds, retry the http request with the new token. Also, stop the waiting for new token mode, no need to listen to other events like that.
- if refresh token fails, well no need to retry. Just unsubscribe from the waiting for new token mode.

It should work, but there are some corner case scenarios that I probably haven't thought of.

Feel free to critique.
Could've said only USA and China!

As a rule, it's a good practice to use functional component whenever possible rather than class-based component. As these lifecycle methods are only available in class-based components, when exactly to use these. I read some blogs but did't exactly understand when exactly to use them in a real-world app. Anyone have some idea or some links to undertand these with examples.
are these lifecycle hooks mandatory or are only used for performance issues ?

Lifecycle hooks are used for different purposes. They are not mandatory, but for certain tasks, you need them. 
e.g.: If you want to load data from a server into your component when your app starts, you will need componentDidMount.

It's just hooks in certain points in the life cycle of a component where you can execute some stuff
Thank you.
No worries :) I'm happy to help.
ComponentDidUpdate is rather easy to understand, but I still can't understand the other ones lol
Good article.
Andreas Reiterer I guess life cycle hook used to load data from server to the component is componentWillMount

Ashwat Acharya from what I've learned in my research, you would use componentWillMount for doing some configuration stuff like setting up a Firebase connection or something similar. 

You can load data in componentWillMount, but if you use this.setState(...) it could be possible that your component will not be re-rendered. Meaning: You have the data in your state, but no one will see it because it's not rendered. 

If you instead load the data in componentDidMount, the component is ready + when the data arrives from the backend and you put it into the state, the component will be re-rendered and display your data. :)
Pretty succinct thank you Andreas Reiterer😊
Also, componentWillMount will only update and render if componentShouldUpdate is set to true right AndreasReiterer ?

Hey :) I wrote an article about life cycle methods, maybe this is helpful for you?
http://www.andreasreiterer.at/web-development/reactjs-lifecycle-methods/?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=comment

basically they are simpler to use. There are some more low level differences as well (like 'this' context). But it's a pretty simple rule to follow.. unless you need to hook in, and perform an action on any of the lifecycle method, use functional components... if you need to use a lifecycle method, you shouldn't be afraid to use a class based component. like performing a server query when the component mounts.
Mikael Pettersson great answer

It's more like a preference rather than a good practice. Functional components are particularly preferred for declaring stateless/dumb components. However, using class based components for the same purpose makes no difference.

The most annoying thing about using function components everywhere is that once I need to add a method or a lifecycle hook, I need to refactor it to a class component. Besides, there are no other advantages of using them except looking a little simple. I'm not convinced.

In my opinion, function components just helps you stick to View and Logic (container) separation. This helps you to think of creating views without depending on local information, and always thinking in the same direction. Should you've a class, you might not take a second to think why not to add that extra method or state to it.

Logic for data fetching, validation etc are useful to separate. But separating logic like animations, event listeners which are tightly coupled to the component, local component state like input text etc. don't have to be separate. It unnecessarily makes things more complicated than it needs to be.
I dunno, I never added a method or state because I could, I add them when I need to. If the component was a function and not a class, If refactor it to be a class and add those.

Agree to the necessity stuff, you've to use local properties. I generally use multiple methods in that case. But if has a form or require state in my dumb components folder , I don't hesitate to. It's all self opinion based choice. All I make sure is I "try" to keep containers separate, and views separate. Infact, I even create seperate controller files to only handle data fetching logic instead of writing all in container. It just simplifies things.
Why is it a good practice to use function components?

up till today, in my company we had two major applications which each had a server serving their static content as well as backend api (one node server doing both, using express, for each application).
we feel its time to make a common api server for these and future applications as well,
so my questions are :
1. is it good practice for each app to have some node server which will make http requests to that api server and have some business logic layer to digest the data spicifically for the application's needs? and not make requests the api server straight from the client (which i'm guessing will have CORS trouble as well as security issues)
2. if i have say a complex query for data involving multiple entities and digesting, and this query is relevant to more than one app, should it be part of the api server? or should i always keep the api server very flat, only reaching for data per entity etc?
thanks

Or just have one monolithic api that has routes for all types of requests and handles everything(simpler to implement but slower performance and less modular) really depends if you need to scale for many users at a time or not
Is it still good practice to have a backend server such as nodejs to be sort of a business logic layer to encapsulate multiple calls to the api and digest data for the app?

Shahar Taite Id say yes but it depends, nodejs is really good to a point. If you start needing to handle tens of thousands or more of users/http requests at a time I’d suggest either many nodejs servers each handling portions of the workload(with a gateway server routing the requests to the correct micro services) or start using Golang servers which candle handle massive traffic, therefore less need for as many servers a node would need.  I’ve heard Each golang server can handle up to 250,000 api requests at a time and is at least twice as fast as nodejs(the developer who created nodejs switched to using golang)
I would need to go through some backend server on the same domain anyway right? To avoid cors
Shahar Taite you can do that or use a cors module to whitelist your frontend domain and have separate servers
A micro service architecture may be a good fit for you

Fetch is better than Axios and more Easy

credentials: include
axios.get for fetching and axios.post for posting data.
And you will be basically reinventing axios when you make the wrapper.

I mean... sure. If you need that degree of flexibility (or you need things like request cancellation), then axios is great. However, including an additional 12kb of dependencies just to make a few HTTP requests seems like overkill to me.
(although I accept that including a fetch polyfill would also be ~12kb)

Fetch is by far the simplest approach - it is designed to replace XHR and includes sensible defaults for the modern web. The fact that it doesn't send credentials by default is a GOOD thing.

if you have such a big issue sending the `credentials` option, then just make a wrapper around fetch which sets your defaults.
